reviewText: I'm sorry but there was just nothing original or noteworthy about this film about a father and son who learn to 'bond' while taking their family's tree to be planted in Washington DC.  Along the way the boy meets up with his online girl 'friend' who decides to tag along, without Dad knowing... and gruff Dad starts having feelings for the go-getter PR woman (and vice-versa) traveling behind them arranging for media attention.  The plot was predictable from the get-go, and the acting was uninspired.... about as 'wooden' as the tree they are carrying in the back of the big rig.  Mediocre Hallmark viewing here; certainly NOT worth buying the dvd in my humble opinion.
summary: tired rehash of father-son bonding scenario

reviewText: How do you make a film about a tree and keep it interesting? Hallmark Channel did it. And it's family approved by DOVE which means it's family rated. Although a live tree is being moved overland from the northwest to DC, it is not really the tree that makes this story, and the only thing Christmas about it is the lighting of a decorated tree at the end.It's another story about Father/Son relationships. But this is somewhat more realistic because it shows that sometimes Dad can be as wrong as son. And along the way, there is a beautiful lady friend for both to begin to love. Sound to sappy for the men, maybe not. There is the...well, I almost spoiled the viewing by beginning to explain some of the action on the road trip. Andrew McCarthy makes a realistic acting tree farmer dad, and Evan Williams does a good job at being the tech-savvy son. I even learned a new term (vlog)which for much younger folk, will wonder where I've been for years.My answer to the negative reaction to a teenager who doesn't always listen to his father is, "reality." It's a parent/child reality show. But a bonding takes place and mistakes are made, and forgiven, and life goes on in a better world as a result.Don't wait for a Christmas season to watch this one, even if the box cover does suggest a holiday film.
summary: FAMILY VIEWING, FEEL-GOOD, MORE ROMANCE THAN CHRISTMAS

reviewText: This was a movie that I wish I had watched with my teenage girls.  I felt like the relationship between the parent and teen was not perfect, but that was the point.  They argued, but then, they learned from each other too. They also learned from foolish mistakes.  Yes, this is a tree-hugging movie.  But, guess what?  It's got tree in the title, so people who love trees are bound to be watching it!  I never really "bought" Andrew McCarthy in a tough-guy role (He also tries it out in Seasons of the Heart), but his romance is believable and sweet.  The teenage boy is very high-energy and a little hyper for me, but I think that is his appeal, and what makes him so different from his father. Overall, a great movie, Christmas or any time.
summary: Something for the teens and the parents
